Cambridgeshire has 136 CQC registered homecare providers and funds 32,712 hours of 
homecare per week (March 2023 figures). Of the providers which have been rated by CQC, 
91% were found to be Good or Outstanding. This is above the national average of 89%. 
Homecare capacity is highly dynamic and difficult to measure across the entire market, so 
the Council uses proxy measures such as waiting times for care to determine if there are 
sufficiency areas. The most recent data suggests that sufficient capacity is available with 
minimal waits for care in Cambridgeshire. It should be noted that this is not always the case. 
Challenges remain in rural and hard to reach areas to provide sustainable and cost-effective 
care for people with complex needs.

If you are concerned about the costs of your home care in Cambridgeshire, you may be eligible for financial assistance based on a financial assessment conducted by the council.

- **Financial Assessment**: The council will assess your financial circumstances to determine if you qualify for financial support. This assessment considers your income, savings, capital, and any benefits you receive. If your savings are above the threshold of **£23,250**, you may need to pay the full cost of your care. However, if your savings fall below this threshold, you might be eligible for council support.

- **Savings Threshold**: The current personal savings threshold is **£23,250**. If your savings are approaching this limit, it is advisable to contact the council for a financial assessment one to two months before you reach the threshold.

- **Next Steps**: You should contact Cambridgeshire County Council to arrange a financial assessment. They can provide more detailed information about potential contributions towards your care costs and guide you through the process.

For more information, you can visit the Cambridgeshire County Council's website at [www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk](https://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk) and search for financial support for care services.
